Award.AwardTitle: Increasing the Recruitment, Retention, and Advancement of Women in STEM at Indiana's Community College System (ivy WiSTEM)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: Ivy Tech, Indiana's state-wide system of community colleges, proposes to conduct a statewide investigation of differences in the hiring and advancement of STEM women in both full-time and adjunct positions. They have four basic goals including: the collection and processing of institutional data on recruitment, retention, and advancement of women in STEM; review available sources and models for institutional transformation; garner institutional support for transformation; and develop a comprehensive transformation plan. Some of the strategies they will use to accomplish their goals are surveys, focus groups, guest speakers, and visits to other ADVANCE institutions. Information about women in STEM at community colleges is lacking in the literature and as the largest community college system in the country, this proposal presents a unique opportunity to collect a large amount of information about this understudied population. As designed, the potential for model building and significant data collection are outstanding. The enormous role that community colleges play in the production of STEM professionals, including eventual PhD recipients and URM STEM professionals is well documented. Understanding the hiring, retention, and promotion STEM women faculty in this setting would contribute greatly to the literature base.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Ivy Tech Community College of Indiana's (Ivy Tech) Women in STEM grant (IvyWiSTEM) proposed an investigation of the hiring and advancement of female STEM full-time and adjunct faculty, with a goal of increasing the hiring and advancement of female STEM faculty at each of Ivy Tech’s 31 degree-granting locations throughout the state of Indiana. Ivy Tech is the nation's largest singly accredited statewide community college system and serves more than 200,000 students annually.  IvyWiSTEM sought to build institutional support for a Transformative Plan for the College through the following activities: 

  • Ivy Tech’s Institutional Research Department assisted IvyWiSTEM Principle Investigators in preparing, disseminating, and reviewing a Faculty/Staff survey to gauge: satisfaction with the College (in regard to length of time employed and by promotion), considerations for leaving the College, reasons for applying to the College, and faculty experiences (negative, positive, and in regard to equity and discrimination).
  • A total of seven (7) Focus Groups were conducted across the state of Indiana and included female STEM faculty representatives from each of the College's 14 regions. Each focus group was recorded by the focus group leader and transcribed by team members at Ohio University's Center for Higher Education. Combined, more than nine (9) hours of recorded audio was collected. Audio files were later transcribed verbatim and analyzed by team members at Ohio University's Center for Higher Education.
  • A survey of STEM-related organizational partners was also conducted to get a sense of how Ivy Tech STEM programs are viewed by an external audience. 
  • An internal Advisory Board was created to assist the Principle Investigator in promoting participation in IvyWiSTEM activities across the state, and to review all data collected through internal and external activities.
  • A two-part professional development opportunity, entitled “Recruiting, Retaining, and Advancing within STEM fields for Women”, was made available to faculty through GoTo Webinar, with over 100 attendees participating.  

 

 

 

 

 

Outcomes/Findings: Intellectual Merit & Broader Impact

The work performed throughout the life of the IvyWiSTEM project serves to increase the awareness of recruitment and retention within STEM fields for female faculty at community colleges, an important addition to the existing retention/advancement research focused on four-year research institutions. Further, it is the hope of IvyWiSTEM participants that the work performed during this grant will serve to inform other community colleges about processes for engaging female faculty in discussions about advancement and retention. Further, once the transformative plan is approved by College leadership, dissemination to other community colleges nationwide will begin as the methods employed throughout IvyWiSTEM are scalable and replicable to other systems throughout the United States.
